docs.abstract: Americans in their mid-60s could live nearly three more decades, research shows, so a healthy dose of stock in your portfolio is actually prudent now.
docs.snippet: Americans in their mid-60s could live nearly three more decades, research shows, so a healthy dose of stock in your portfolio is actually prudent now.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you’re on the cusp of retirement or have just stopped working, it’s hard to tune out the stock market’s recent gyrations.

headline.main: Retiring Into a Shaky Market? Think Long Term Anyway
headline.print_headline: Retiring Into a Shaky Market? Think Long Term, Still

docs.abstract: With a name evoking another era, the blue sheets of metal also tell a tale of China’s growth — and of the steep bills coming due.
docs.snippet: With a name evoking another era, the blue sheets of metal also tell a tale of China’s growth — and of the steep bills coming due.
docs.lead_paragraph: They call it the “Blue Great Wall.”

headline.main: A ‘Blue Great Wall’ Divides a City as It Battles the Coronavirus
headline.print_headline: A ‘Blue Great Wall’ Against a New Invader

byline.original: By Yuyang Liu and Cao Li

docs.abstract: One wrote about being asked to move out by a landlord in Europe. Others described fleeing China to escape the epidemic.
docs.snippet: One wrote about being asked to move out by a landlord in Europe. Others described fleeing China to escape the epidemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus outbreak has radiated to at least 77 countries, killing more than 3,200 people and infecting more than 93,000. It has paralyzed cities and towns, disrupted business, travel and schools. But no place has seen more devastation than China, where the overwhelming majority of deaths and infections have occurred.

headline.main: ‘A Slap in the Face’: Chinese Readers Share Their Coronavirus Stories
headline.print_headline: Feelings of Suspicion, Fear and Loneliness, From All Over the World

docs.abstract: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
docs.snippet: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
docs.lead_paragraph: On March 1, the day after the first coronavirus death in the United States was announced, brothers Matt and Noah Colvin set out in a silver S.U.V. to pick up some hand sanitizer. Driving around Chattanooga, Tenn., they hit a Dollar Tree, then a Walmart, a Staples and a Home Depot. At each store, they cleaned out the shelves.

headline.main: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them
headline.print_headline: ‘Crazy Money’ in a Pandemic, Selling $70 Bottles of Sanitizer

docs.abstract: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates to near-zero and said it would buy up huge amounts of government and mortgage-backed debt in an effort backstop the United States economy.
docs.snippet: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates to near-zero and said it would buy up huge amounts of government and mortgage-backed debt in an effort backstop the United States economy.
docs.lead_paragraph: This briefing is no longer updating. Live coverage can be found here.

headline.main: Markets Unsteady as Fed Signals Urgency of Economic Threat

docs.abstract: The tech giant, which will keep its stores in the China region open, becomes one of the first retailers to shut its doors in an effort to halt the spread of the coronavirus.
docs.snippet: The tech giant, which will keep its stores in the China region open, becomes one of the first retailers to shut its doors in an effort to halt the spread of the coronavirus.
docs.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Apple said it would close most of its retail stores outside mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, becoming one of the first companies to take such a drastic measure to fight the coronavirus outbreak.

headline.main: Apple Closes Most of Its Stores for 2 Weeks

docs.abstract: A proposal would loosen federal rules meant to control infections, just as the coronavirus rips through nursing homes.
docs.snippet: A proposal would loosen federal rules meant to control infections, just as the coronavirus rips through nursing homes.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has been working to relax regulations governing America’s nursing homes, including rules meant to curb deadly infections among elderly residents.

headline.main: Trump Administration Is Relaxing Oversight of Nursing Homes
headline.print_headline: Regulator Intends To Relax Oversight In Nursing Homes

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

byline.original: By Jesse Drucker and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

docs.abstract: Many tech employees have the luxury of working from home in an emergency. But companies like Uber, Airbnb and WeWork could end up hurting.
docs.snippet: Many tech employees have the luxury of working from home in an emergency. But companies like Uber, Airbnb and WeWork could end up hurting.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Gigs at Home, but Not What Start-Ups Intended
headline.print_headline: With Tom Hanks Infected, It’s Getting Real

docs.abstract: Social media companies are delivering reliable information in the coronavirus crisis. Why can’t they do that all the time?
docs.snippet: Social media companies are delivering reliable information in the coronavirus crisis. Why can’t they do that all the time?
docs.lead_paragraph: For some Americans, reality arrived Jan. 25, when a Harvard epidemiologist tweeted “HOLY MOTHER OF GOD.” Or on Feb. 29, when researchers announced they had found cases in Seattle.

headline.main: When Facebook Is More Trustworthy Than the President
headline.print_headline: On Virus, Social Media Has Come Into Its Own

docs.abstract: Universal is breaking longstanding industry practice to offer “The Hunt,” “The Invisible Man” and “Emma” for streaming.
docs.snippet: Universal is breaking longstanding industry practice to offer “The Hunt,” “The Invisible Man” and “Emma” for streaming.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Universal Pictures said on Monday that it would no longer give theaters an exclusive period of roughly 90 days to play new movies, a break with longstanding Hollywood practice that could have wide-ranging reverberations. The decision, prompted by the coronavirus pandemic and likely to anger theater owners, makes Universal the first old-line studio to become more like Netflix in its approach to film distribution.

headline.main: Studio’s Movies in Theaters Will Be Offered for In-Home Rental
headline.print_headline: Moviegoers Stay Home. Studio Joins Them.

byline.original: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
